snippet.textDisplay: Jeremy Soule is too good.
snippet.textOriginal: Jeremy Soule is too good.

snippet.textDisplay: Man, I love this soundtrack. I would have to agree with many on here in saying that this game is superior to Skyrim, both in musical score and the world/gameplay. If there was ever going to be a game that was remastered for the current gen (and there are way too many boring games being remastered), I would hope that it would be this one. Especially after being able to see every item in your inventory in full 3D in Skyrim, it is hard to go back and play this game. Oh, and nothing in the Elder Scrolls universe will ever be as epic as Shivering Isles for me. Loved that DLC.
snippet.textOriginal: Man, I love this soundtrack. I would have to agree with many on here in saying that this game is superior to Skyrim, both in musical score and the world/gameplay. If there was ever going to be a game that was remastered for the current gen (and there are way too many boring games being remastered), I would hope that it would be this one. Especially after being able to see every item in your inventory in full 3D in Skyrim, it is hard to go back and play this game. Oh, and nothing in the Elder Scrolls universe will ever be as epic as Shivering Isles for me. Loved that DLC.

snippet.textDisplay: The worst game in the best series (ie the worst of the best).
snippet.textOriginal: The worst game in the best series (ie the worst of the best).

snippet.textDisplay:
@Zack Devro Yeah, and Skyrim still seems pretty bad when it comes to the dungeons as well. Most enemies you encounter are the same ones over and over again, and the loot is pretty much always a nordic war axe (only this time with 20 ice damage omfg!), lol. No different from Oblivion in that respect.

Overall, Oblivion all the way.
snippet.textOriginal:
@Zack Devro Yeah, and Skyrim still seems pretty bad when it comes to the dungeons as well. Most enemies you encounter are the same ones over and over again, and the loot is pretty much always a nordic war axe (only this time with 20 ice damage omfg!), lol. No different from Oblivion in that respect.

Overall, Oblivion all the way.

snippet.textDisplay: +Chameleonard Shame they didn't bring back the arena. I loved the glitches on Oblivion where you could hover above them on the gates and just shoot arrows at your opponents to win. Even if the game was broken and linear in terms of the dungeons, I had more fun on here than dull and boring Skyrim.
snippet.textOriginal: +Chameleonard Shame they didn't bring back the arena. I loved the glitches on Oblivion where you could hover above them on the gates and just shoot arrows at your opponents to win. Even if the game was broken and linear in terms of the dungeons, I had more fun on here than dull and boring Skyrim.

snippet.textDisplay:
+JourneytoNewZealand I can't speak for him, but I found Skyrim's side quests (and even the main quest) to be less interesting and shallower than Oblivion's. In Oblivion you had amazing Dark Brotherhood quests filled with intrigue, mystery, nastiness and creepiness. In Skyrim... not as much. Skyrim's quests don't seem as well written or engrossing as Oblivion's, and like I said, not as deep. Skyrim also mainly has a lot of quests -- quantity over quality. Most of those quests are just 'kill bandit/dragon x in location y'. Don't get me wrong, I'm not saying Skyrim's quests sucked, but there's a good case to be made for them being worse than Oblivion's, and some are downright boring and easy. I honestly hardly even remember Skyrim's quests, which is weird since I played Skyrim for a while. Oblivion's quests, though... all the Dark Brotherhood quests, the Shivering Isles quests, the Fighter's Guild and Blackwood Company, the Mythic Dawn, the Mages' Guild, Canvas the Castle, the arena... more memorable than Skyrim, more fun.

I also found Skyrim to be depressing when it comes to the graphics. I mean, I get that the province is supposed to be bleak, cold, and often barren, but sometimes it felt like it could've used more color. Maybe more interesting sky effects, more varied buildings and building interiors, etc etc. Even the inns in this game (which are supposed to look warm and inviting) just looked kind of bland and cold to me. Fire usually seems pale yellow in Skyrim, and everything is just so serious and bleak that it gets annoying after a while.

These reviews explain it pretty well:
http://www.gamefaqs.com/pc/615805-the-elder-scrolls-v-skyrim/reviews/review-150200

http://www.gamefaqs.com/pc/615805-the-elder-scrolls-v-skyrim/reviews/review-149090

Skyrim's quests don't seem as well written or engrossing as Oblivion's, and like I said, not as deep. Skyrim also mainly has a lot of quests -- quantity over quality. Most of those quests are just 'kill bandit/dragon x in location y'. Don't get me wrong, I'm not saying Skyrim's quests sucked, but there's a good case to be made for them being worse than Oblivion's, and some are downright boring and easy. I honestly hardly even remember Skyrim's quests, which is weird since I played Skyrim for a while. Oblivion's quests, though... all the Dark Brotherhood quests, the Shivering Isles quests, the Fighter's Guild and Blackwood Company, the Mythic Dawn, the Mages' Guild, Canvas the Castle, the arena... more memorable than Skyrim, more fun.

I also found Skyrim to be depressing when it comes to the graphics. Fire usually seems pale yellow in Skyrim, and everything is just so serious and bleak that it gets annoying after a while.

These reviews explain it pretty well:

snippet.textDisplay: Ahh, good times. The first few notes instantly take me back to this adventure, blown away by the graphics at the time (with all its bloom effects). The game was far from perfect, but it still managed to pull me in like few other series can. Soule's music plays a big role in that.
